answers.author: Barry Crook
answers.text:
Non-issue. There is nothing "bad" about at-will employment -- why would you want to remain employed by a City Council that no longer wants you as their manager? You can deal with your concerns with an employment contract -- that's enough law governing your relationship with the council.

answers.author: Peter Gardner
answers.text:
Non-issue. I have worked since 1976 until 2008, at 5 cities without a contract. I have a contract now because the Commission wanted me to have it. I have been terminated once - 30 years ago, but in all my employment opportunities I have been respectful of the councils and citizens, and they have treated me fairly. If you do that, even if you a asked to leave, you will find another position.

answers.author: Roderick Wood
answers.text:
The reason for at will employment for executives is that the City Council is the duly elected body by the people and must have the ability to have a city manger they have full faith and confidence.  Your security is that it requires a majority of the Council to terminate you and in a sound Employment Agreement.  You should not work for a Council that will not approve a reasonable contract of terms and conditions and a reasonable severance provision.  I had 12 months because that is how long it typically takes a terminated manager in California to get a new position.  The same s true why city manager's want the department heads, the city manager must have full faith and confidence in a department head or be able to replace them at will.  The wrong city manager can hurt a city council and the wrong department head can hurt a city manager.
I know of no CEO that is not working at will for all the same reasons.  true private sector golden parachutes are often significantly better then public sector, but the option is if that is one's need then work in the private sector.

author: Dennis Stark
text: Should ICMA be asked to work on the issue of "at will" employment? Whoever invented this concept should be... Anyhow, I am not sure what has been done to date, or the background, but there is a substantial investment in our careers. As credentialing gains momentum, this issue deserves serious consideration. No matter what level we reach, to be subjected to arbitrary termination is ridiculous. Is this a non-issue?
title: "At Will" employment
